timeline.bodyText:
First, javadoc please :)
Second, having this class will override context storage for the whole JVM with our agent. Including all our instrumentations. And may change the before of the application, if it already has its own override.
timeline.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
Yeah - I think this is better behavior for Armeria users than the default. When Armeria context isn't available, the behavior is the same as normal so I'm not terribly worried about affecting the JVM.
But this gRPC API is silly so is problematic... indeed most problematic is if the user wants to override this themselves. Best I can think of is to provide our implementation (I extracted into a separate class) so they can delegate to it.
replies.author: anuraaga

replies.bodyText: Have you tested this with the full javaagent? I think (shaded) io.grpc.override.ContextStorageOverride will be in the AgentClassLoader, while (shaded) io.grpc.Context will be in the bootstrap class loader, so may not find the (shaded) io.grpc.override.ContextStorageOverride.
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think this is why the auto unit tests don't work. I'll continue to follow up on it, but any quick ideas on why the java_concurrent instrumentation wouldn't be enough anyways? #979 (comment)
replies.author: anuraaga
